 It depends on what you mean by constant. Wherever we look outside of our galaxy cluster, objects show a red shift, which means that they are moving away from us. However, red shift is not constant. The farther a stellar object is from us, the more red shifted it is. That means that farther an object is from us, the faster it is moving away from us.
 
 But to claim that this means that the earth is the center of the universe is fundamentally ignorant. The earth orbits the sun (not the center of the universe) which orbits the center of our galaxy (not the center of the universe) which orbits the center of our galactic group (not the center of the universe). It really doesn't matter where you are in the universe, you would observe the same expansion of stellar objects away from you.

 But all things aren't "flying away from a point." Wherever did you get that nonsense? It's obvious that the moon is orbiting the earth, not flying away. It's obvious that the earth and the planets aren't flying away from anything. Neither are the moons of the other planets. And neither are the galaxies in our local group "flying away" from anything. All of the above are held together by gravity, and, in fact, gravity is why Andromeda is coming closer.
 
 However, stellar objects outside of our local galaxy cluster do appear to be moving away from us due to the expansion of space/time as a result of the inflation of the universe (the real "big bang") shortly after the quantum event that created it.
 
 By the way, things aren't "flying away" from a point. I know its hard, but please make an effort to educate yourself.
 
 But on the other hand, density variations that explain stellar objects have been explained theoretically (and tested). Thus, there are stars and planets that form solar systems that are part of galaxies, that form galaxy clusters that are held together by gravity. Outside of local clusters, space/time is expanding, which causes the observed red shift. The observed red shift indicates that the further away from us a stellar object is (with the obvious exception of our local galaxy group...duh!), the greater the red shift. That means that the further away from us a stellar object is, the more rapidly the expansion of space/time is carrying it away from us.

 This is pretty much the reason why I said I'm not a big fan of the big bangtheory myself. It starts off with an observation: light coming from distant stars give off light with more red-end spectrum. It is interpreted as cosmic bodies moving away from each other (an interpretation I don't really agree with), and then it just goes downhill from there.

This is pretty much the reason why I said I'm not a big fan of the big bangtheory myself. It starts off with an observation: light coming from distant stars give off light with more red-end spectrum. It is interpreted as cosmic bodies moving away from each other (an interpretation I don't really agree with), and then it just goes downhill from there.

 
 It' not that the light is different it is the fact that there is more space (metric expansion) in the way.

This is pretty much the reason why I said I'm not a big fan of the big bangtheory myself. It starts off with an observation: light coming from distant stars give off light with more red-end spectrum. It is interpreted as cosmic bodies moving away from each other (an interpretation I don't really agree with), and then it just goes downhill from there.
It's not that there is 'more red-end spectrum' light, it's more complicated than that.
 
 Fusion (that thing which makes the sun shine) gives out light of all colours, so if you split up sunlight (with a very good prism, for example), you should get this:
 http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/57/Spectral_lines_continous.png
 
 However, you don't. What you actually get looks more like this: 
 http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b8/Spectral_lines_absorption.png
 
 Those dark lines are called 'absorption lines'. They're there because helium (what the sun is mostly made of) always absorbs light of certain wavelengths, letting the rest pass through. We see those absorbed wavelengths as black lines. Every (transparent) chemical element has a very specific 'signature' of absorption lines; this means that if we shine white light through a gas, we can tell exactly what gas it is by looking at the pattern of dark lines. This method is used to find out what stars are made of; by analysing the light they give off.
 
 However, if you look at stars in other galaxies, you find that the absorption spectrum has shifted. It's the exact same pattern, but all of those lines from a single star have shifted by the same amount (a varying number of wavelengths) towards the red (longer wavelength) end of the spectrum. There are two possible causes of this that we know of - one is that the source is moving away from us at speeds such that relativistic doppler effects come into play, and the other is that space itself is expanding, stretching out the light as it does so.
 
 What's more - if you look at stars that are even further away, you will find that their 'red shift' is even more pronounced. This indicates that the entire (observable) universe is expanding, taking every galaxy further and further away from every other galaxy.
 
 So we have an expanding universe. The rest, on the surface of it, is simple - imagine time running backwards, and you have a shrinking universe. Run back far enough, and we have a universe that is a single point. This idea that everything was in one place at one time (or at least, very close) is also supported by the CMBR - the fact that the background 'temperature' of the universe is exactly what it would be if a "fairly uniformly distributed red-hot gas is expanded to the current size of the universe." 
 
 Now, approaching the boundaries (of that single point), I agree fully that things get... weird. But that's another story.

There are two possible causes of this that we know of - one is that the source is moving away from us at speeds such that relativistic doppler effects come into play, and the other is that space itself is expanding, stretching out the light as it does so.
 
 What's more - if you look at stars that are even further away, you will find that their 'red shift' is even more pronounced. This indicates that the entire (observable) universe is expanding, taking every galaxy further and further away from every other galaxy.
 
 So we have an expanding universe. The rest, on the surface of it, is simple - imagine time running backwards, and you have a shrinking universe. Run back far enough, and we have a universe that is a single point. This idea that everything was in one place at one time (or at least, very close) is also supported by the CMBR - the fact that the background 'temperature' of the universe is exactly what it would be if a "fairly uniformly distributed red-hot gas is expanded to the current size of the universe." 
 
 Now, approaching the boundaries (of that single point), I agree fully that things get... weird. But that's another story.

 What an exceptional explanation of red shift! You are to be congratulated.
 
 Most often, creationists are swayed by scientific illiterates such as Mr. Kent Hovind (currently a federal prisoner), who make claims that light from distant stars isn't red. And creationists, rather than investigate, accept what he tells them as truth. They also believe him when he calls himself "doctor". In fact, he has no degree from any accredited college or university. He claims to have taught "science" for a number of years (14 as I recall). But he isn't, and never was certified as a teacher at any level. He taught in an unaccredited religious school at the elementary level. His students were most likely classified as "home schooled" by his state.
 
 Why are there so many creationist frauds?

evolution and the big bang are two separate theories and they should be treated as such. one compliments the other in the same way they each compliment atheism, but they are not linked in any way. they arent even in the same fields of study! one is intense physics and astronomy and mathematics while one is biology and chemistry and population dynamics.

 Your point about the lack of a necessary connection between evolution by natural selection and the Big Bang is right on.
 
 It's worth keeping in mind, though, that they can compliment theism just as well. After all, the originator of the Big Bang was a Catholic priest. And there are religiously devout biologists, like Ken Miller or Francis Collins, and scientifically informed theologians, like John Haught or John Shelby Spong, who accept evolution, reject YEC, and reject the notion that ID is science.
 
 What I find sad about religion anymore is the way it gets further and further reduced to superstitious literalism -- and by the "true believers" themselves.

My favourite argument for pantheism runs as such: If God is the greatest entity possible, then God cannot be a separate entity from the universe as there would then be a possible entity which is greater than God - ie God and the universe combined. As such, God is the universe, each and every thing.
 
 Woo pantheism, etc.

 Indeed. Deism, pantheism, there are lots of options. Frankly, I'd even say that traditional theism complete with a supernaturally intervening deity is an option, so long as one doesn't think that such miraculous interventions trump scientific understanding of the normal operations of the universe, or that such miraculous interventions are a part of science themselves.
 
 The difficulty is, any of these options requires that one abandon a literal interpretation of the Bible. There are good theological grounds for doing so, even scriptural grounds: witness the inconsistency of Genesis 1 and Genesis 2! Despite the myriad problems with ostensibly literal interpretations, a whole lot of people are adamantly against dropping them.

My favourite argument for pantheism runs as such: If God is the greatest entity possible, then God cannot be a separate entity from the universe as there would then be a possible entity which is greater than God - ie God and the universe combined. As such, God is the universe, each and every thing.
 
 Woo pantheism, etc.

 Agree here too. Respectfully submitting the words of Archbishop Desmond Tutu: 
 
 
Tutu says he still reads the Bible everyday but recommends that people don't believe everything it teaches. 
 
 "You have to understand is that the bible is really a library of books and it has different categories of material," he said. 
 
 "There are certain parts which you have to say no to. The Bible accepted slavery. St Paul said women should not speak in church at all and there are people who have used that to say women should not be ordained. There are many things that you shouldn't accept." 
 http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/12/15/ctw.tutu.climate.interv iew/index.html
